customer_addr:

Great Falls, VA 22066

citations.narrative:
The facility’s program of veterinary for dogs is incomplete and does not contain all the required information. There is no
specific vaccination schedule stated for distemper, parvo, or rabies virus vaccines. Additionally, the program does not
contain the testing frequency to monitor internal parasites such as heartworm, intestinal parasites, and external parasites.
There is no specific frequency for preventative care and treatment to ensure healthy and unmatted hair coats, properly
trimmed nails, and clean and healthy eyes, ears, skin, and teeth. An incomplete program of veterinary for dogs can lead
to a negative impact on their health and well-being. Correct by 6 August 2024 by ensuring the program of veterinary care
for dogs is complete and contains all the required components.

The indoor portion of the white-handed gibbon sheltered enclosure is unable to meet the standards for temperature
regulation. The ambient temperature was exceeding 100 degrees F and the indoor housing did not have an effective
method of controlling high temperatures. During inspection, the temperature on the gauge appeared to be about 96
degrees F. Excessively hot temperatures for non-human primates can lead to overheating and unnecessary discomfort.
Correct by 23 July 2024 by ensuring that the sheltered portion of the sheltered housing for non-human primates does not
exceed 85 degrees F for more than 4 consecutive hours.

The perimeter fence at the facility has not been maintained to function as a secondary containment system or restrict
animals and unauthorized persons from entering the facility. In the llama pasture near the shelter, the perimeter fence is
missing multiple metal clips that attach the top of the fence to the supporting fence posts. The top of the fence has started
to bend down under the weight of vegetation, no longer maintaining the required height in fencing. Additionally, in the
lower left corner of the upper field, a section of three consecutive fence posts is no longer attached to the perimeter chain
link fence. Inspectors were able to push down on the top of the fence, away from the posts, creating at least a 3-foot gap.
Inadequate perimeter fences can allow predators and other animals or unauthorized people into the facility, which can
unnecessarily endanger the animals in the collection. Additionally, the fence no longer serves as a secondary
containment, and animals may be able to breach the perimeter of the facility and become harmed or injured. Correct by 6
August 2024 by ensuring the perimeter fence is constructed so that it protects animals in the facility by restricting animals
and unauthorized persons from going through or under it and so that it can function as a secondary containment system.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with ______.
Additional Inspectors:
Robert Ferguson, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER
Mary Ann Archer, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.13(a) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The facility’s program of veterinary for dogs is incomplete and does not contain all the required information. There is no 
specific vaccination schedule stated for distemper, parvo, or rabies virus vaccines. Additionally, the program does not 
contain the testing frequency to monitor internal parasites such as heartworm, intestinal parasites, and external parasites. 
There is no specific frequency for preventative care and treatment to ensure healthy and unmatted hair coats, properly 
trimmed nails, and clean and healthy eyes, ears, skin, and teeth. An incomplete program of veterinary for dogs can lead 
to a negative impact on their health and well-being. Correct by 6 August 2024 by ensuring the program of veterinary care 
for dogs is complete and contains all the required components. 
3.77(a) 
   
Sheltered housing facilities. 
The indoor portion of the white-handed gibbon sheltered enclosure is unable to meet the standards for temperature 
regulation. The ambient temperature was exceeding 100 degrees F and the indoor housing did not have an effective 
method of controlling high temperatures. During inspection, the temperature on the gauge appeared to be about 96 
degrees F. Excessively hot temperatures for non-human primates can lead to overheating and unnecessary discomfort. 
Correct by 23 July 2024 by ensuring that the sheltered portion of the sheltered housing for non-human primates does not 
exceed 85 degrees F for more than 4 consecutive hours. 
3.127(d) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
The perimeter fence at the facility has not been maintained to function as a secondary containment system or restrict 
animals and unauthorized persons from entering the facility. In the llama pasture near the shelter, the perimeter fence is 
missing multiple metal clips that attach the top of the fence to the supporting fence posts. The top of the fence has started 
to bend down under the weight of vegetation, no longer maintaining the required height in fencing. Additionally, in the 
lower left corner of the upper field, a section of three consecutive fence posts is no longer attached to the perimeter chain 
link fence. Inspectors were able to push down on the top of the fence, away from the posts, creating at least a 3-foot gap. 
Inadequate perimeter fences can allow predators and other animals or unauthorized people into the facility, which can 
unnecessarily endanger the animals in the collection. Additionally, the fence no longer serves as a secondary 
containment, and animals may be able to breach the perimeter of the facility and become harmed or injured. Correct by 6

August 2024 by ensuring the perimeter fence is constructed so that it protects animals in the facility by restricting animals 
and unauthorized persons from going through or under it and so that it can function as a secondary containment system. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with ______. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Robert Ferguson, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER 
Mary Ann Archer, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
